loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is from the village of Central Poblacion, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Gloria is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Gloria buys and sells rice and corn grains in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Gloria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional sacks of rice and corn grains. This will be Gloria's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice and corn grains

loans.name: Danilon Marina

texts.en:
Danilon Marina is a 35-year-old married woman living in Libag Sur, Tuguegarao City. She has three school-aged children. Danilon Marina's spouse works as a driver in one of the schools in the city.

Danilon Marina has been in the business of hog breeding and fattening for future sale for three years and she earns approximately PHP 5,000 monthly. She is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000. She plans to use this loan to purchase additional pigs to raise and to buy medicines to ensure good nutrition.

In the future, Danilon Marina would like to diversify her business in order to achieve financial independence and continuously send her children to school and have a brighter future.

loans.use: to purchase additional pigs and medicines

loans.name: Semi

texts.en:
Semi is a 35-year-old man who is married to Yumima, a 33-year-old lady. They have a son, Simson, who is in the third grade of elementary school.
 
Prior to running a poultry business, Semi used to work in a private company for almost six years. He was dismissed by the company in 2007. Semi realized that he had to earn money to fulfill his family's needs, so he started a poultry business as the income source for his family. In the beginning of his business, Semi lost many chicks because of disease. But this did not prevent him from trying again. With his own small capital generated from working as a motorcycle taxi driver, Semi restarted the business by purchasing some boxes of chicks to be raised. 

Semi dreams of enlarging his poultry business. Therefore, he is requesting a loan from TLM amounting to 3,000,000 IDR. With the loan, he would like to purchase 200 chicks and fodder. He hopes that the loan application will be approved by TLM.

loans.use: to purchase 200 chicks and fodder

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios is from the village of Frankfort, Bumbaran, Lanao del Sur. She is 23 years old. Remedios is single and has one small child. To make a living, Remedios runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in the local community. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Remedios joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, snack foods, and beverages. This will be Remedios' first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, snack foods, and beverages

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a married woman with four adult-aged children. She is 51 years old and has had a food-selling business for 20 years.

Monica sells fruits and vegetables to the people in her community. She has been in the business for 20 years. Monica is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase more variety of fruits and vegetables like apples, mangoes, cabbages, tomatoes, etc.

In the future, Monica hopes to strengthen her business to make frequent sales and became more profitable.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn, from the village of Amoyong, Wao, Lanao del Sur, is 52 years old, married and has five grown children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting her fourth loan for 14000 PHP to purchase more canned goods, snack foods and beverages. Evelyn plans to use the extra revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages.

loans.name: Nelda

texts.en:
Nelda, age 41, earns a living by running a general store in the local community. Nelda has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities. She and her husband have four school-aged children and live in the village of Fatima, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. 
 
In 2010, Nelda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Nelda has successfully repaid her most recent previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. 

Nelda is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase more products such as shampoo, soap, and home goods needed for her general store business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Nelda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more products such as shampoo, soap, and home goods needed for her general store business

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en:
Pilar is a hardworking entrepreneur living in the Philippines. She is a 58-year-old married woman. Pilar has three children. Pilar's spouse works as a carpenter.

Pilar has been in the business of hog raising for 15 years. Each month Pilar earns PHP 7,000. She plans to use this loan to purchase additional pigs to raise and to buy building materials to renovate the pigpen.

Pilar has been a client of ASKI for 15 years. In the future, Pilar would like earn consistent profits and provide a better life to her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional pigs to raise and to buy building materials to renovate the pigpen.

loans.name: Alejandro

texts.en:
Alejandro, age 54, earns a living by offering transportation services, specifically motorela or habal-habal services, to local community members. Alejandro has been engaged in his business for over 11 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. He also purchases and sells fruits along with his wife. They have six grown children and live in the village of Eastern, Wao, Lanao del Sur. 
 
In 2009, Alejandro joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. He wished to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Alejandro has successfully repaid his most recent previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and was employed as working capital. 

Alejandro is now requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools needed for his business as well as to help pay for his utilities. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Alejandro from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 
 
About HSPFI:
 
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.
 
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for his business as well as to help pay for his utilities

loans.name: Guddi's Group

texts.en:
Guddi is married. Her husband sells milk and yogurt. His shop is located in the market and his business is going very well, because he offers his clients good quality products. Guddi stays at home and does her household responsibilities. She has given birth to a son, who is 23 years old and in the same business as his father. 

Guddi has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her son who wants to start his own business selling milk and yogurt. With the loan, he will buy milk in large quantity which will help him increase his profits and allow him to do business independently. Guddi is hopeful that the loan investment will be a great step towards the growth of her son’s business. 

Guddi is a regular user of Asasah and this is her third loan application. In previous years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. In the photo, the lady with a book (an Asasah passbook) is Guddi.

loans.use: To buy milk for selling.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bicycle spare parts for his business.

loans.name: Dusangire Ii Group

texts.fr:
Régine est une commerçante âgée de 40ans qui habite au chef lieu de la Province de Kayanza située au Nord du Burundi. Elle  fait le commerce de produits alimentaires principalement les choux depuis 20 ans et elle est en même temps cultivatrice. Elle est veuve et mère de 4 enfants âgés respectivement de 14ans, 12ans, 10ans et 6ans qui étudient. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 4e année primaire. 
Elle habite une  maison qu’elle loue mais a l’espoir que son business va être florissant pour lui permettre d’acheter une parcelle pour construire sa propre maison.  
 
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter son capital en agrandissant la quantite de choux a acheter pour revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. Elle espère que son business va croitre considérablement pour lui permettre d’assurer la scolarité de ses enfants.
 
Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire« Dusangire II».
texts.en:
Régine is a trader who is 40 years old and lives in the county town of Kayanza province, which lies in the north of Burundi. She has been selling food products, mainly cabbages, for the past 20 years and is at the same time a farmer. She is a widow and mother to four children who are 14, 12, 10 and 6 years old respectively; they are all at school. She attended school up until the fourth year of primary school. She lives in a house which she rents, but hopes that her business will flourish and allow her to buy a piece of land on which she can build her own house.

She is a asking for a Kiva loan in order to increase her capital and expand the amount of cabbage she can buy for reselling in order to make a good profit. She hopes that her business will grow considerably and enable her to pay for her children's schooling. 

She is a member of the "Dusangire II" community group.

loans.use: to expand her stock of cabbage for reselling

loans.name: Sawe Rahayu Indah Group

texts.en:
Ni Komang is a pig farmer in her village. Because she wanted to improve the welfare of her village, she formed a group of pig farmers and teaches them how to raise pigs so they can succeed. For financial support, the group borrowed from MUK. Ni Komang and the ten members of this group received loans of 1.5 million Indonesian rupiah per member to be used to buy three piglets. They hope their efforts will be successful and they will be independent. 

Ni Komang is in the front row on the far right.

loans.use: to buy three piglets.

loans.name: Jennie

texts.en:
Jennie is from the village of Thailand, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 35 years old.  She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jennie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, shampoo, soap, spices, food seasoning & vegetables in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Jennie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. That loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. 

Jennie is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP to purchase additional products like canned goods, snack foods & beverages to sell. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchase more products to resell

loans.name: Sro

texts.en:
Sro is a resident in the Komong Chame Province. She is a domestic farmer. She was married, but her husband passed way from an illness many years ago. 

Sro grows different kinds of crops on her existing farmland. From this business, she can make a profit of about $2 each day to cover the family’s needs. She will be using her loan to dig a pond, and to buy fish food and small fish for feeding. Sro lives in a wooden house with her five children, two of whom are working in different locations while the other three are single.

loans.use: to dig a pond, and to buy fish food and small fish for feeding.

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
Guillerma is from the village of Manukan. She is 62 years old, married, and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Guillerma owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community.  She has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Guillerma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Guillerma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients to make bibingka (rice cake). This will be her 4th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: buy raw ingredients to make rice cakes to sell

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en: Maxima is married and 59 years old. She has a retail shop where she sells snacks and daily used products such as soap, shampoo, and toothpaste in the local community. She has had this business for 10 years. Maxima is requesting a loan of PHP 22,000 to purchase more retail items such as canned goods, soft drinks, and instant noodles that would increase the capacity of sales in her business. Each month, she earns about PHP 9,000 doing this type of work. In the future, Maxima hopes to have a big business, achieve financial independence and provide a better life for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more retail items to sell such as canned goods, soft drinks, and instant noodles.

loans.name: Novelyn

texts.en:
Novelyn is from the village of Wadya, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 45 years old.  She widowed and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Novelyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Novelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI.  That loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. 

Novelyn is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP to purchase additional snack foods, canned goods & beverages to sell. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: buy additional products to resell

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda  is from the village of Malintuboan, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 50 years old, married, and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Luzminda owns & operates a fishing business.  She harvests wild-caught fish as well as buy and sell fish in the local community. Luzminda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Luzminda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC.  That loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell. 

Luzminda is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to purchase more fish to sell. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is from the village of Wadya, Banisilan, Cotabato. She is 32 years old.  She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. That loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital. 

Marilou is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to purchase more canned goods, beverages & snack foods to sell. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: buy  more inventory for her store

loans.name: Said

texts.ru: Саид житель района Хамадони. Ему 74 года. Он женат, имеет 9 детей. Его дети живут отдельно. А жена, работает учительницей в средней школе. Сам Саид пенсионер. У него имеется высшее образование. По профессии он педагог. В этой области проработал 35 лет. На сегодняшний день он занимается животноводством. В основном он закупает скот с других местностей и разводит у себя дома. Через несколько дней или месяцев он вывозит скот на рынок и продает по более выгодной цене. Этим видом деятельности он занимается 2 года. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en: Said lives in Hamadoni. He is 74 years old, married, and has nine children. His children live separately. His wife works as high school teacher. Said is on a pension. He has a higher education. He is a teacher by profession.  He taught for 35 years.  Now he works in animal husbandry.  Basically he buys cattle from other districts and raises them at home. After a few days or months he takes the cattle to the market and sells them for a profit. He has been doing this work for two years.  He is taking out a loan to buy more cattle.

loans.use: to buy more cattle.

loans.name: Saqiba Idress' Group

texts.en:
Saqiba Idress is married with three children: two sons and a daughter. All of them are very young and have not started their education yet. Her husband is a farmer by profession. He owns a small piece of land where he grows different seasonal crops and sells to the required customers. Saqiba is a housewife who prefers to stay at home and do her household work. She is a very active and efficient lady and performs her work efficiently. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further improvement of her husband’s agriculture business. With the loan, he will purchase fertilizers, seeds and pesticides to grow better crops and increase his profits. Saqiba is hopeful that a loan will help her husband to fulfill his client's orders and improve the living standard of her family as a result of increased profits. She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Saqiba Idress.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides

loans.name: Chipenyo

texts.en:
Chipenyo is a married woman with nine children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past 3 years, Chipenyo has been operating a business selling dry fish.  She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby.  She faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation because of the increase in fuel prices. Chipenyo dreams of expanding her business in the future. 

With the loan for Kshs 20,000,  Chipenyo wants to purchase more fish to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: buy more dry fish to sell

loans.name: Ankhtsetseg

texts.en:
Ankhtsetseg is 23 years old and lives with her husband, grandmother, son and daughter, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in the outer ger districts of the city. Her son is 4 years old and her daughter is 1 year old. Her grandmother is retired and cares for the children at home. 

Ankhtsetseg started running her carpentry business with help from her husband in 2007. When they first began their business, they did not have any equipment. Now they have some carpentry equipment and usually make wooden washstands, wooden beds and other furniture.  They purchase wood from Tsaiz wood market and sell their products at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. 

Ankhtsetseg is requesting a loan of 700,000 MNT to purchase more wood to make furniture.  She and her husband want to improve their business with this loan so they will be able to build their own small house.

loans.use: buy more wood to make furniture

loans.name: Ki

texts.en:
Mrs. Ki is shown in the picture with her little son. She is 40 years old and has lived with family members in the Baray district of Kompong Tom since 1979. She currently generates income by selling pork in the local market from pigs that she and her husband slaughter in a cage behind their house. Besides this, her husband sells firewood in and around his community for additional income. 

Mrs. Ki’s husband was using an old cart to pick his firewood to sell, but it broke while in the operating process. He wishes to replace it in order to have an easy way to transport his items. To help this situation, Mrs. Ki would like to ask for a loan for her husband to buy a new cart in order to replace the broken one.

loans.use: to buy a new cart for her husband to replace a broken one used to gather firewood for sale.

loans.name: Ameeran's Group

texts.en:
Ameeran is married with two sons. Her elder son works in a factory and her youngest son is 16 years old and stays at home. Ameeran couldn’t afford his education due to financial constraints. Her husband operates a lathe machine and repairs tools and iron items. He is expert in his work and earns a good profit every month from his work. Ameeran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy another lathe machine, which will help him expand his business by involving his younger son in his business. Ameeran is hopeful that a loan will help her husband make more income and improve the living standard of her family. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Ameeran.

loans.use: To buy another lathe machine

loans.name: Ludivina

texts.en:
Ludivina is from the village of Taguilon, Dapitan City. She is 62 years old.  She is widowed and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Ludivina owns & operates a specialized retail store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community.  She has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Ludivina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. That loan was used to purchase additional inventory & fund working capital.

Ludivina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase more stocks for her sari-sari (retail store). This will be her 10th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: buy more inventory for her sari-sari (retail) store

loans.name: Thor

texts.en:
Thor, age 48, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Thor grows vegetables, earning an income of $2.50 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also supported by her husband who raises cows and buffaloes, earning an income of $2 per day. Their  standard of living has improved since Thor has had her business. 

Thor is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase dirt to fill out the land at the back of her house to grow more kinds of vegetables. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: buy soil for her vegetable farm

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en: Sarom, age 47, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Sarom sells vegetables, earning an income of $8.5 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also supported by her husband who buys and sells cows, earning an income of $6.5 per day. Their  standard of living has improved since Sarom has had her business.  She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase more vegetables to resell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a KIVA partner.

loans.use: buy more vegetables to resell

loans.name: Senzakahle Group

texts.en:
Lindiwe is 36 years old and married with four children between the ages of 16 and 19, three of whom attend school. For two years she has run a business selling live chickens from her home in Kwa Zulu Natal of Empangeni, South Africa and also receives income from the government's child grant program. In the photo she is pictured rasing her hand.

Lindiwe is requesting this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy more chickens to sell. She says that customers who take her products on credit and fail to pay on time are her main business challenge. The extra income arising from this loan will help her business grow and enable her to better support her family.

loans.use: to buy chickens for her business.

loans.name: Leoum

texts.en:
Leoum, age 31, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Leoum sells food, earning an income of $5 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband, who is a security guard who earns an income of $4 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since Leoum has had this business. 

She is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase more supplements to expand her current business. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more supplements to expand her food business.

loans.name: Grecelda

texts.en:
Grecelda is from the village of Kipaducan, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 35 years old. Grecelda is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Grecelda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack food, beverages, candy, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in the local community. Grecelda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities. This picture shows Grecelda and her son.

In 2009, Grecelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Grecelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory, and as working capital. Grecelda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, snack food, and biscuits. This loan will be Grecelda's third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, snack food, and biscuits.

loans.name: Lea

texts.en: Lea, age 28, is married and lives with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Lea is a singer, earning an income of $6 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who sells groceries, earning an income of $5 per day. The family's standard of living has improved since Lea and her husband have started these businesses. Lea is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to stock the store.

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is a married woman with four children. Three of them attend school, and one is still too young for school. She owns a house that has piped water but no electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past ten years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to local customers. Dorothy sells items for household consumption, such as maize flour, sugar, and tea leaves. Her other source of income is a mobile phone charging business. One of the major challenges Dorothy faces in her business is the high cost of transportation. 

With the Kshs 40,000 loan she wants to buy one sack of sugar, two bundles of wheat flour, and two bundles of maize flour. She decided to join Yehu to get access to loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase one sack of sugar, two bundles of wheat flour, and two bundles of maize flour.

loans.name: Maria Lee

texts.en:
Maria Lee is from the village of Salvacion, Kadingilan, Bukidnon. She is 32 years old. Maria Lee is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Maria Lee owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack food, beverages, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in the local community. Maria Lee has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maria Lee joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Lee has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Maria Lee is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack food, and beverages. This loan will be Maria Lee's fourth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack food, and beverages.

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en: Sophal, age 29, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia.  Sophal is a farmer and she also sells traditional cakes, earning an income of $6 per day to help cover the family expenses.  Their standard of living has improved since Sophal has had this business.  She is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike to transport cakes to resell.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Rolina

texts.en:
Rolina is from the village of Tuburan, Villaflor, Oroquieta City.  She is 27 years old, married and has one adult-aged children.  To make a living, Rolina runs a general store. 

Rolina has been engaged in her business for 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.  Rolina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. 

Rolina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP with which she will purchase more products such as home chores need for her general store business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Rolina from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchased more products such as home chores needed for her general store business.

loans.name: Hameedan's Group

texts.en:
Hameedan is a caring & supportive lady who stays at home and does her household work. She is married and her husband runs a grocery store in the community. He sells daily use items like lentils, cooking oil, spices, etc. to his clients at reasonable rates. 

Hameedan also supports her husband by visiting his grocery store and handling his clients. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s grocery store business. With the loan, he will buy groceries in bulk to put in his store and sell.

She is confident that her husband's business will be improved after the loan and her family will be able to enjoy a better living standard as a result.  

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Hameedan.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk to sell

loans.name: Abashizehamwe Group

texts.fr:
Justine est une commerçante âgée de 33ans qui habite la Commune de Rugombo à l’Ouest du Burundi. Elle  fait le commerce de la bière locale de bananes depuis 2 ans et elle est en même temps cultivatrice. Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants âgés respectivement de 14ans, 13ans, 8ans et 1an. Trois sont à l’école. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. 
 
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter son capital en produisant une grande quantite de biere locale de bananes et agrandir son activité pour réaliser de grands bénéfices. Elle espère que son business va croitre considérablement pour lui permettre d’assurer la scolarité de ses enfants, pour vivre plus aisément et acheter une parcelle pour construire sa propre maison. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  solidaire« Abashizehamwe».
texts.en:
Justine is a 33 years old merchant residing in Rugombo Township in western Burundi. She has been trading in local banana beer for two years, and simultaneously is a farmer. She is married and the mother of four children aged respectively 14, 13, 8 and 1. Three of the children attend school. She went to school up to sixth grade.
 
She is requesting a Kiva loan to increase her capital and produce a large quantity of local banana beer and expand her business to make large profits. She hopes that her activity will grow considerably, so that she can live more easily and purchase a lot on which to build her own house.

She is a member of the "Abashizehamwe" solidarity group.

loans.use: to buy raw materials to produce a large quantity of banana beer to sell

loans.name: Somley

texts.en: Somley, age 39, is married and resides with her husband and children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Somley raises pigs and buys cows to resell, earning an income of $7 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who raises pigs to resell, earning an income of $5 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since Somley and her husband have had these businesses. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to purchase more cows to resell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy cows to resell

loans.name: Teht

texts.en:
Mrs. Teht, 36, owns a small shop in front of her house where she sells coffee and other soft drinks. She typically makes around $4.50 in profit each day to ensure that her family has a comfortable life. Her husband helps her with the business. She has three kids, all of whom sell different kinds of products in their own kiosk next to their house. 

Mrs. Teht is concerned that she is hardly going anywhere, and she dreams of having a vehicle, but she doesn’t have money yet to buy one. Therefore, Mrs. Teht would like to borrow a loan to purchase a secondhand motorcycle for traveling needs. With the rest, she will use to buy a new cask for selling meatballs.

loans.use: to purchase a secondhand motorcycle for traveling needs and to buy a new cask for selling meatballs.

loans.name: Kwakwanya Group

texts.fr:
Gertrude is a 40-year-old saleswoman who lives in the seat of the Ruyigi province, located in Eastern Burundi. She sells food products such as dried fish, known locally as "ndagala", cooking salt, and other products such as laundry soap. She has had this business for the past 4 years, and she also maintains a market garden. She is married to Leonidas, who is also a salesman, and they do not have children. She takes care of two children, who are her husbands children with his first wife, who is deceased. She went to school until the 6th year of primary school.

She requested a Kiva loan in order to increase her working capital to buy large quantities of food products to resell in order to make a large profit. She hopes that her business will grow significantly, so that she can provide enough food for her family.

She is a member of the Kwakwanya solidarity group.


Translated from French by Kathy Guis


Gertrude est une commerçante âgée de 40ans qui habite au chef lieu de la Province de Ruyigi située à l’Est du Burundi. Elle  fait le commerce de produits alimentaires comme le poisson sec communément appelé « ndagala », du sel de cuisine et d’autres comme des savons de lessive, etc depuis 4 ans et elle est en même temps cultivatrice. Elle est mariée a Leonidas lui-même commerçant mais n’ont pas d’enfant. Elle prend en charge 2 enfants de son mari qu’il a eu avec sa première épouse décédée. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantites de produits alimentaires a revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. Elle espère que son business va croitre considérablement pour lui permettre d’assurer les besoins élémentaires familiaux. 
 
Elle est membre  du groupe  solidaire« Kwakwanya».

loans.use: augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantites de produits a revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices

loans.name: Jovita

texts.en:
Jovita is from the village of Salvacion, Kadingilan, Bukidnon. She is 65 years old. Jovita is married and has 5 adult-age children. To make a living, Jovita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling  canned goods, junk food, beverages,shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. Jovita has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jovita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Jovita is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk food & beverages. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jovita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk food & beverages

loans.name: Saloon

texts.en: Saloon, age 29, is married and resides with her husband and children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Saloon sells fish, earning an income of $6 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who a construction worker, earning an income of $5 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since Saloon and her husband have had these businesses. She is requesting a loan of $900 to purchase a motorbike to transport fish to resell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Muhammadi

texts.ru: Мухаммад проживает в районе Хамадони. Ему 22 года. Холост. Живет вместе с матерью и сестрами. Его мама инвалид, а отец умер три года назад. Он один работает в семье. Он занимается животноводством. Зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. В основном он разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Этим видом деятельности  занимается  уже год. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Muhammadi lives in Hamadoni. He is 22 years old and single. He lives with his mother and sisters. His mother is an invalid, and his father died three years ago. He is the only one working in the family. He works in animal husbandry. He earns money by raising cattle. Basically he breeds cattle for sale. He has been doing this work for a year.  He is taking out a loan to buy cattle.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Sambo

texts.en: Sambo, age 34, is married and resides with her husband and children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Sambo produces traditional baskets and sells souvenirs, earning an income of $6 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who is a construction worker, earning an income of $5 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since Sambo and her husband have had these businesses. She is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase rice to stock for sale. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy rice in stock for sale

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita lives in the village of Malintuboan, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 43 years old, married and has three school-aged children. For the last three years, she has made a living by selling fish and earns about 3,000 PHP a month.

Earlier this year, Elenita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC and is applying for a new loan, for 10,000 PHP, to buy more fish to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional fish to sell.

loans.name: Genevieve

texts.en:
Genevieve is 34 years old and married with five school-aged children. Genevieve is a farmer working in the Philippines who earns PHP 5,000 per month. 

Genevieve is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase additional fingerlings and feed. Genevieve has been managing a fish raising business for five years.

In the future, Genevieve hopes to strengthen this kind of business by raising more fish for sale. She believes that if there is patience and sacrifice, she can achieve her goal and give her children a better future. She is very thankful with the financial assistance of the Kiva lenders who assist her in the business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fingerlings and feed

loans.name: Bo

texts.en: Bo, age 47, is married and lives with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She makes a living as a tailor, earning an income of $1.50 per day to help cover her family's expenses. Her husband is a farmer and earns about $3 per day. Their family's standard of living has improved since Bo and her husband opened their businesses. She is applying for a loan of $700 to buy a tuk-tuk (or motorized vehicle) for her husband to use to transport tourists to nearby temples. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorized vehicle to carry tourists to local temples.

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo lives in the village of Bangahan, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. He is 37 years old, married and has two school-aged children. For the last five years, he has made a living by making and selling chicken and pork kebabs and barbecue to the people in his community and earns about 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Reynaldo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. Her has repaid a loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI and is applying for a new one, for 8,000 PHP, to buy ingredients such as meat, spices and seasonings. He plans to use the additional revenue he earns to expand his business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for a barbecue business.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam, age 60, is married and lives with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She is a housewife while her husband makes a living repairing temples, earning an income of $5 per day to help cover family expenses. The family's standard of living has improved since her husband began his current business. She is requesting a loan of $800 to buy a motorbike for their children to use to commute to school. This is her first loan application to CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella lives in the village of Villa Sudiacal, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 36 years old, married and has three school-aged children. For the last 10 years, she has made a living by running a general store and earns about 3,000 PHP a month.

Earlier this year, Estrella joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC and is applying for a new one, for 7,000 PHP, to buy additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell.

location.town: Villa Sudiacal, Liloy, ZAmboanga Del Norte

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine, from the village of Malipayon, Pangantucan, Bukidnon, is 43 years old, married and has two grown children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she is requesting her second loan for 8000 PHP to purchase more canned goods, snack foods and beverages. Josephine plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her store.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages.

loans.name: Zaira's Group

texts.en:
Zaira, the leader of this group, is 31, married to a farmer, and the mother of two sons; the first son is at school and the second is yet too young to attend.

In order to earn money to meet the family's needs, Zaira sells fruits and vegetables in the market. She started this activity three years ago with an initial investment of 15000 soms and now earns 6000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Zaira wants to purchase more vegetables for resale. In the future she wishes to save money to purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Vun

texts.en: Vun, age 32, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia where she sells food, earning an income of $10 per day to help cover the family's expenses. The family is also assisted by her mother who sells fried noodles, earning an income of $5 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since Vun has had this business. She is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase more products to expand her food-selling business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more products to expand her food-selling business.

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Im, 41, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Im sells food, earning an income of $5 per day to help cover the family's expenses, while her husband sells souvenirs for tourists, earning an income of $5 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since Im has had her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase more souvenirs for her husband to resell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more souvenirs for her husband to resell.

loans.name: Ngen

texts.en:
Mr. Ngen is a hardworking man who always tries to earn money to support his family with many kinds of expenses. He has good skills with making wooden chairs and wooden tables for a furniture shop in Siem Reap province. He can earn an income in average of $3.25 a day from his job. He has a life partner in his wife who is a rice grower. They have four single children and most of them are attending a local school. 

With this loan, Mr. Ngen will purchase a plot of a plantation from a villager in order to grow bananas. This will enable the family to accrue an extra profit to meet their daily expenses.

loans.use: to purchase a plot of plantation for growing bananas.

loans.name: Yuth

texts.en: Yuth, age 63, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Yuth is a housewife, while her husband is a security guard at the temples, earning an income of $2 per day to help cover the family expenses. Their standard of living has been improved because Yuth’s husband is employed. She is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en: Fe is from the village of Kuguita, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 39 years old. Fe is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Fe buys and sells seafood products, including fish like sardines and mackerel. Fe has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2009, Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Fe is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish, like sardines and mackerel. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Fe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish, like sardines and mackerel.

loans.name: Kousar's Group

texts.en:
Kousar has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her beauty salon business. She is a beautician and has good experience in her field. She is especially known for her bridal makeup.  With the loan, she will buy cosmetics and beauty products to improve her services for her clients and increase her revenue. She is confident that after the loan, her business will start giving her more profits and she will be able to support her family better. She is the mother of two children. Both of her children are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. Her daughter is studying in class 3rd while her son is studying in class one. Her husband works in a factory for a low income. She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for herself and her family. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Kousar.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and beauty products for her beauty salon

loans.name: Khetholuhle Group

texts.en:
Sibongile is 31 years old and single with three children between the ages of 5 and 9. All three children attend school. She runs a clothing business in Kwa Zulu Natal in Empangeni, South Africa. In the photo she is pictured raising her hand.

She’s been in the business for two years and sell clothes to the community from her home. She requested this loan through WDB and Kiva so that she could start selling groceries in her shop. 

She says that the main challenges to her business are customers who buy clothes on credit and fail to pay on time.  She says that the extra income from this loan will help her take care of her children and generate more profit. In the future, she see herself having room to sell so that she does not inconvenience her children in the house.

loans.use: To start selling groceries in her shop

loans.name: Chheoun

texts.en:
Chheoun, age 57, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Chheoun sells groceries and vegetables, earning an income of $15 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband, who provides motorbike-washing services, earning an income of $3 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since Chheoun has had this business. 

She is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to stock the store.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy is 33 years old and married with an 8-year-old child. She runs a salon to earn a living. She has been in the business for nine years. She appreciates Faulu Kenya because she has gained a lot of business skills from the training conducted by Faulu Kenya. She has used her previous loans from Faulu Kenya to grow her business.  

She has requested 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy shampoos, hair braids and hair oil.

loans.use: to buy shampoos, hair braids and hair oil.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Vann, age 28, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia.  Van and her husband produce traditional drums to resell, earning an income of $7 each per day to help cover the family expenses.  Their standard of living has been improved since Vann has had this business. She is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a machine to help produce the drums.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a machine to help produce drums

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a single man who owns a house with electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expense is electricity bills.

For the past three years, he has operated a printing business. He also does lamination, mobile phone charging, and sales of mobile phone accessories. His potential customers are the neighbouring college students and other people in the community. He dreams of becoming a distributor of stationery in the future.

With this loan of Kshs 20,000, he wants to purchase stationery for his printing business. He decided to join Yehu to get access to loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase printing stationery for his business.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz  is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 41 years old. Luz is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Luz owns and operates a business buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing in the local community. Luz has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Luz joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Luz has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16000 PHP from HSPFI. The previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Luz is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which she will use to purchase additional t-shirts and blouses to sell. This will be Luz's 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional t-shirts and blouses

loans.name: Nourn

texts.en: Nourn, age 39, is married and resides with her family in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Nourn sells groceries, earning an income of $5 per day to help cover the family's expenses. The family's standard of living has improved since Nourn has had this business. The family is also supported by her husband who is a construction worker, earning an income of $6 per day. Nourn is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase more construction supplies to expand her husband’s business. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies to expand her husband's business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pipes and padlocks

loans.name: Cyril

texts.en:
Cyril is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. He is 39 years old. Cyril is single. To make a living, Cyril owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. He sells canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Cyril has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Cyril joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cyril has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. The previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Cyril is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and beverages. This will be Cyril's 4th loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and beverages

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is from the village of Gusa, Calatunan, Sindangan. She is 37 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Victoria works as a baby-sitter (nanny). Victoria has been engaged in this work for 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. Victoria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which she will use to pay her children's tuition fees. This will be Victoria's tenth loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:   Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders

loans.use: to pay her children's tuition fees

location.town: Gusa, Calatunan, Sindangan, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Rwenyonyozi Tukore Group

texts.en:
She is on the sunny side of 29, a stickler for diligence, highly spirited, focused and enterprising. These are all attributes which describe this happily married mother of four who goes by the name of Carolina. The business she bears a hand in is a lucrative business, but very highly competitive in nature. Food sales has been her business enterprise for the past decade. Carolina operates her business from the main food market in Ntungamo. The fact that she owns a farm has been a vantage point of sorts. She has been able to take in stride the high demands from her clients because she is able to harvest and sell what she grows. This coupled with her other stocks in trade have enabled her to make significant headway throughout the years. 

Carolina has mostly been selling bananas, beans, rice, cabbage, and ground nuts. She says her monthly sales revenue is 60,000 shillings and she says with this Kiva loan, she is going to purchase more beans, rice, ground nuts, and cabbage seeds to plant. She thinks this will increase her harvest after the crops mature. She also envisions better sales profits in the future with increased sales.

loans.use: to purchase more beans, rice, ground nuts and cabbage seeds to plant.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is from the village of Cabuan, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 53 years old. Rosita is widowed and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosita owns & operates a business buying and selling coconuts for copra in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP to purchase additional coconuts & green bananas. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Rosita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts & green bananas

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa is from the village of Lopoc, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 33 years old. Josefa is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Josefa owns & operates a fishing business harvesting & selling wild-caught fish in the local community. Josefa has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Josefa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josefa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Josefa is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Josefa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Nita

texts.en:
Nita is from the village of Agoho, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 50 years old. Nita is separated from her spouse and has two adult children. 

To make a living, Nita buys and sells coconuts for copra (dried coconut meat used in oil production). Nita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Nita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Nita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional coconuts for copra. This will be the third loan taken out by Nita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional coconuts for copra.

loans.name: Daniel Junior

texts.pt:
Daniel Junior Daniel, nasceu na Provincia de Inhambane Sul de Moçambique, casado e cem filhos ainda. Fez a 10ª classe não continuou devido a dificuldades financeiras. vive na casa dos tios e responsabiliza se pela sua mãe e irãmos que vivem em Inhambane enviando lhes em cada 3 meses 1.000.00mt.

Daniel sai de Inhambane para o Distrito de Namaacha com seu irmão, onde da continuida dos seus estudos, interrope quando aranja um emprego na saúde como Motorista porque o horário de trabalho é feito em turnos não fixos, dependendo muito mais das emergências que surgem no seu sector. E permanente a 4 anos auferindo 4.401.69mt que aplica nas dispesas da casa e da sua obra. Para alem do salario, tem subcidios de 725.00mt de risco em cada saida que faz no trabalho. Consegue poupar na sua conta bancaria 1000.00mt porque tem ajuda da sua esposa que e emfermeira.

Ja teve empréstimo no BIM , conhece a Hluvuku atraves do amigo que é cliente da instituição. Este é seu terceiro  empréstimo na Hluvuku e primeiro com Kiva no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção( cimento, e material electrico) para fazer a estalação de energia da sua casa. Os empréstimos  anteriores foram de 7.000.00mt e 10.000.00mt para habitação.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente para poder aceder a outros créditos no futuro. Pretende solitar novos empréstimos para concluir a sua obra.
texts.en:
Daniel Junior was born in Inhambane Province in southern Mozambique. He is married and does not yet have children. He finished 10th grade but did not continue because of financial problems. He lives in his aunt and uncle's house and takes care of his mother and siblings, who live in Inhambane, by sending them 1,000 meticais every three months.

Daniel left Inhambane to move to Namaacha District with his brother, where he continued his studies. He quit school when he got a job as a driver for the Health Department because the work schedule has irregular shifts, depending mainly on how many emergencies come up in his sector. Daniel has been a permanent employee for four years and earns 4,401.69 meticais, which he uses for household expenses and his construction project.
